title: Ordinary terraced house transformed into horror display for Halloween
text:
Would you dare trick or treat here? (Picture: PA)

You might be used to seeing Christmas displays pop up from December, with lights and Father Christmases brightening houses.

Now, a family are taking things a step further by transforming their entire terraced home into a house of horrors.

They will no doubt give passing drivers a fright with the ghoulish decorations, including a ghost suspended from the second floor and a set of gallows in the garden.

There is a skeletal bat and a giant tarantula, as well as a zombie nun, guillotine and a demon riding a bicycle.

Francis McIsaac and partner Julie Smith spent nine days preparing their end-of-terrace house in Norris Green, Liverpool, for the spooky season.

Ice cream man Mr McIsaac, 51, said: ‘We’ve been doing this about six years. We started doing it for our own kids when they were younger and it just grew and grew.’

The end-of-terrace house is transformed each Halloween (Picture: PA)

Dark (Picture: PA)

There’s even a spooky dog next to the electric chair (Picture: PA)

There’s someone in the stocks (Picture: PA)

Would you go to visit? (Picture: PA)

‘It’s nice to give something back to the community.’

Advertisement

If you live nearby, you can go and check it out as the gardens are open for people to look around between 6pm and 9pm in the week leading up to Halloween.

The family are collecting donates for nearby Sandfield Park School, for children with disabilities.

Mr McIsaac, a grandfather-of-four, makes many of the moving props himself in the garage of the house, and on Halloween itself the family put on costumes to scare the visitors.

He said: ‘People love the house, although their reactions are not so good when we jump out at them.

‘There are children who have been coming to see it since they were one and are now seven years old.

There’s a spooky circus (Picture: PA)

The three witches (Picture: PA)

They’ve recreated Freddy Krueger (Picture: PA)

Ghoul on a trike (Picture: PA)

A man-eating spider (Picture: PA)

‘My partner enjoys Halloween more than me, but I like making all the props.

‘Usually it takes me six to eight hours to make something, but if it’s an animated prop it can take a little longer.’

Last year, the house of horrors made £700 for the school, but the couple hope to raise even more.

Mr McIsaac said: ‘This year we have had more than 2,000 shares of the pictures we put on Facebook.

‘Last year we had to close the doors and only let a few people in at a time and this year we think it will be even busier.’
